page.title: 10HOME LIFE IN CRUWYS MORCHARD
page.content: The weekly routine of farming and business families differs in one respect. The former choose working hours and meal-times to fit in with the daily tasks. The latter have a rigid pattern of fixed hours, light lunches and evening meals. Children are away at school all day. In 1962 electricity arrived, with it better lighting and many appliances. Farmhouses have Rayburn-type cookers run on solid fuel, oil, liquid gas or wood, providing hot water. All other homes have electric or liquid gas cookers. There are no local stores. Fridges and deep-freezers ensure variety and availability of perishable food. Pasties alternate with pizzas, curries vie with casseroles. Many homes now have central-heating, 99% have television. Telephones are needed as there is only one public box.
